intro: Dorothea divergens, commonly known as the forked dandelion, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which is characterized by its composite flower heads and distinctive leaf structures. The plant features a basal rosette of deeply lobed, serrated leaves that are typically hairy and grayish-green in color. Its flowering stems rise from the center of the rosette, bearing yellow composite flowers that bloom in the spring. Dorothea divergens is often found in moist, open habitats such as meadows and woodland edges.
